Title.En: Image Analysis for Intelligent Systems in Medicine

Description.En: This Micro-Module is structured into introduction, self-learning, and implementation phases. First, you will get input on recent feature extraction and data analysis methods. You will work in a small team of three to four students solving detection and classification tasks on medical image data. In particular, your task is to automatically detect surgical tools and their motion in endoscopic images. To tune and test your algorithms we will provide image data from a surgical daVinci imaging system acquired in our laboratory. Participating in image annotation also allows you to better understand AI models and their limitations. Finally, we will test your algorithms on real medical image data. You can compare your results directly with other groups through our online leaderboard.

Title.En: Gain practical experiences in medical image analysis

PrefLabel.En: evaluate data, information and digital content

NoteLiteral.En: At the end of the course learner will gained a practical experiences in acquiring, pre-processing and analyzing medical image data.
At the end of the course the learner is able to implement data analysis algotithm using principles of artificial intelligence.
At the end of the course learners solved coding taks successfully in a team and forster their skills in collaborative problem-solving.

Title.En: Image Analysis for Intelligent Systems in Medicine
Image Analysis for Intelligent Systems in Medicine

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
The Micro-Module starts in mid-November. In the beginning, we will arrange virtual meetings and online tutorials to provide you with the most important basics required for delving into the project. The course is offered in a hybrid format to enable participation on-site (TUHH) and abroad.

The implementation phases are intended to be tackled asynchronously and in small teams, fostering collaborative problem-solving. We will schedule regular online meetings to discuss your approach, answer open question and support you throughout the implementation process. Meetings will be offered every 2-3 weeks on Thursday afternoon.

For students from abroad it is optionally possible and recommended to also attend the lecture ‘Intelligent Systems in Medicine’, which will take place every Friday starting from 18. October from 3 to 6 pm (CET) hybrid on site (TUHH) and on Zoom. You will receive one additional ECTS point for regular attendance of this lecture. Further information on the lecture will follow.

Feel free to contact us (maximilian.neidhardt@tuhh.de) if you have any questions.
Gain hands-on experience in developing AI for medical image analysis

AI is becoming an increasingly important tool for clinical tasks, e.g., medical image processing or decision making. In this course you will have the opportunity to learn the fundamentals of different AI methods and apply these methods practically to real clinical image data. We will provide datasets - acquired partially in our laboratory – to train models on detection and classification tasks for surgical image analysis. You will work in an interdisciplinary and international team on this project.

We particularly encourage students with a background in computer science, data science and/or engineering to apply, but we welcome all other disciplines as well. Please note that basic programming knowledge (e.g. in Python or C++) is a prerequisite for participation.  

To apply, please send a short motivation letter, your CV and your transcript of records (if available) and make sure, all your documents are in English.  

All students who pass will receive a certificate (Microcredential) from ECIU.
